conversations.value:
Here's data for the next scene:
 {
 "game": "Jim Henson’s Labyrinth: The Adventure Game", 
 "chapter": "Stone Walls", 
 "chapter\_description": "The high walls cast long and sinister shadows, déjà vu hides around every corner, and unfamiliarity bombards the senses. From the hill on which you stand, the Labyrinth stretches out before you in its entirety; vast, and impossible.",
 "scene": "THE TRUMPET",
 "description": "The shouts of hundreds of voices ring down the corridors. The maze opens up into a wide amphitheater crowded with denizens of the Labyrinth of every variety: Dwarves, Goblins, Fairies, Worms, and all manner of strange beasts. They seem to be organized into factions that are arguing with one another. On a platform at the front of the amphitheater stands the Trumpet, a massive stone horn the size of an elephant. Just as you enter, a Dwarf blows the Trumpet with an ear-splitting blast, and the whole place goes silent. \"The guests have arrived!\" The Dwarf shouts. \"Let us hear what they have to say for themselves!\"",
 "locations": [
 "The Crowd. Citizens of the Stonewalls have gathered to debate the disturbances caused by the party. Everyone they have met so far is somewhere in the crowd. The mob is physically divided into two groups, those in favor of the party and those against. Several of the Night Trolls are keeping order and holding back the enemies of the party.",
 "The Platform. The party is summoned up to the platform and questions and accusations are hurled at them, one at a time. The party should be given a chance to explain and defend themselves, as many of their actions have become distorted by rumors even over the short time that they've been there. Factions and NPCs that they have allied themselves with will come to their defense. The Dwarf at the front (named Una) acts as the judge of these proceedings and will blow the Trumpet periodically to restore order. Whenever the party responds to an accusation, NPCs run back and forth between the two crowds as people change their minds."
 ],
 "notes": "Debate\nThe Goblin King should use this opportunity to show the players how their actions have impacted the Labyrinth, and how rumors of their actions are spreading. After the Goblin King feels that the back and forth has gone on for long enough, Una will call for a vote, which is decided by a test (difficulty determined by how many enemies the party has made). If the party went through Loma\u2019s door, the roll is improved. If they went through Gloams door, it\u2019s hindered.",
 "consequences": "If they succeed, Una will allow them to speak into the Trumpet. It will be heard all across the Stonewalls and Hedge Maze. Update their progress. If they fail, they'll be thrown in the oubliette (page 42). They can't enter this scene again.",
 "random\_tables": {
 "Random Denizens": [
 "Goblin in yellow raincoat.",
 "Sleepy Giant Badger.",
 "A wall of Helping Hands.",
 "A girl in Goblin armor.",
 "Very tall woman in beret.",
 "Reptilian Goblin hunter.",
 "Gloam the Dwarf.",
 "Stiltt-Bird cocking its head.",
 "Mighty Worm warrior.",
 "Guard who loves riddles.",
 "Goblin with blond hair.",
 "Worm with mustache.",
 "Child-sized newt, liar.",
 "A white stallion.",
 "Dwarf poison merchant.",
 "Loma the Horned Beast.",
 "Dwarf clockmaker.",
 "A man made out of rocks."
 ],
 "Positive Mob Reactions": [
 "They are unconvinced by the argument.",
 "A random denizen cheers.",
 "Polite applause.",
 "Someone shouts \u201cyou\u2019re my hero!\u201d",
 "Standing ovation.",
 "Loud cheering erupts."
 ],
 "Negative Mob Reactions": [
 "They are unconvinced by the argument.",
 "A random denizen boos.",
 "Non-distinct jeering noises.",
 "A drunkard is heckling.",
 "Some people are throwing tomatoes.",
 "People seem offended."
 ]
 }
 },
Remember that this is what you should do as the Goblin King:
1. Describe a transition into this scene from the previous one. 
2. Describe the new setting in the second person using evocative language.
4. Introduce any new non-player characters in this scene by describing their physical characteristics without using their names until they introduce themselves.
5. Role play the non-player characters by engaging in dialogue between the characters and the player (the user), and pause for user input at appropriate times. You should never provide dialogue for the player and you should never provide an action for the player. That's up to the user.
6. You should keep track of what items the player has gathered. They can keep an inventory with a maximum of 6 items.
7. Keep track of a list of all of the NPCs that are accompanying the player, and remember their relationship with the player so far. Role play the NPCs as needed. If any decide to leave describe why, and narrate their exits. The current NPCs that are accompanying the player are: Dame Margot, King Jasper and his loyal jester Wick, the goblins who we rescued from Rum.
8. Ask the player what they want to do.
As you leave the giant's lair and move further into the Labyrinth, you and your companions find yourselves approaching a cacophony of voices. The high stone walls cast long and sinister shadows, creating an eerie atmosphere. The path leads you to a wide amphitheater teeming with denizens of the Labyrinth: Dwarves, Goblins, Fairies, Worms, and all manner of strange beasts. They seem to be organized into factions that are arguing with one another.
On a platform at the front of the amphitheater stands a massive stone horn the size of an elephant, known as the Trumpet. Just as you enter, a Dwarf blows the Trumpet with an ear-splitting blast, and the whole place goes silent. "The guests have arrived!" the Dwarf shouts. "Let us hear what they have to say for themselves!"
Your current companions, Dame Margot, the Goblin King, and the goblin soldiers decide to stay with you in this new scene, while the others opt to leave, fearing the chaos and potential dangers of the debate.
You observe various factions and NPCs that you have encountered before in the crowd. They seem to be physically divided into two groups: those in favor of your party and those against it. Several Night Trolls are maintaining order and keeping your enemies at bay.
The Dwarf at the front, named Una, acts as the judge of the proceedings. You and your companions are summoned up to the platform, where questions and accusations are hurled at you one at a time. It seems that many of your actions have been distorted by rumors.
What do you want to do?

As you leave the giant's lair and move further into the Labyrinth, you and your companions find yourselves approaching a cacophony of voices. The high stone walls cast long and sinister shadows, creating an eerie atmosphere. The path leads you to a wide amphitheater teeming with denizens of the Labyrinth: Dwarves, Goblins, Fairies, Worms, and all manner of strange beasts. They seem to be organized into factions that are arguing with one another.

On a platform at the front of the amphitheater stands a massive stone horn the size of an elephant, known as the Trumpet. Just as you enter, a Dwarf blows the Trumpet with an ear-splitting blast, and the whole place goes silent. "The guests have arrived!" the Dwarf shouts. "Let us hear what they have to say for themselves!"

Your current companions, Dame Margot, King Jasper, Wick the jester, and the goblin soldiers decide to stay with you in this new scene.

You observe various factions and NPCs that you have encountered before in the crowd. They seem to be physically divided into two groups: those in favor of your party and those against it. Several Night Trolls are maintaining order and keeping your enemies at bay.

The Dwarf at the front, named Una, acts as the judge of the proceedings. You and your companions are summoned up to the platform, where questions and accusations are hurled at you one at a time. It seems that many of your actions have been distorted by rumors.

As the debate begins, a goblin in a yellow raincoat steps forward and accuses you of causing chaos within the Labyrinth. A sleepy giant badger, who appears to be on your side, quickly retorts, "But they also saved several of us from dangerous situations!"

What do you want to do?
"What chaos have we caused, pray tell?"

The goblin in the yellow raincoat glares at you and says, "You've caused quite a stir in our peaceful Labyrinth! You've disturbed the sleep of giants, disrupted the order of things, and meddled in our affairs!"

Before you can respond, a very tall woman in a beret from the crowd supporting you interjects, "But they've also been helping those in need and solving problems along the way! They've shown bravery and resourcefulness!"

The crowd murmurs, and some of the denizens seem to be swayed by the arguments. Una, the Dwarf judge, blows the Trumpet to restore order and then gestures for you to address the crowd.

What do you want to say?
